title: Obesity In India Has Doubled In Some Parts Over The Last 10 Years According To This Report. Here’s How To Tackle It - Indiatimes.com
text:
Regi George Jenarius February 22, 2017 
In a shocking revelation by the National Family Health Survey (NFHS-4) the obesity levels in the urban population of Rajasthan has doubled over the last 10 years! 
This disturbing statistic comes at a time when a recent report found a substantial chunk of the urban population of the country in states like Andhra Pradesh, Pondicherry and Sikkim registering an alarming 30 per cent of their population falling under the obese category. 
indianexpress.com People amidst the urban population are worse off 
The survey also reports that 19.7 per cent of the male population is obese in urban areas, as compared to the 10.6 percent in rural areas. And 23.7 per cent of women in urban areas were found to be obese, as compared to the 10.7 percent in rural areas. I t just shows that women in rural areas lead a much more active lifestyle compared to their counterparts in urban areas. 
This comes in the backdrop of the fact that the country is already facing a crisis with heart-related ailments and diabetes on the rise. 
According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), being overweight and obese is defined as an excess accumulation of fat that presents itself as a health risk. Common ailments include diabetes, osteoarthritis, different types of cancers and other lifestyle disorders. 
themonthly.com 
Consensus world over considers a BMI of 30 or more as obese and a person with BMI of 25 or more as overweight. As of 2014, India ranks as the 3rd most obese country in the world. Thanks to a widespread increase in a sedentary lifestyle and other lifestyle changes, these numbers continue to skyrocket. 
WHO states that the fundamental cause of obesity is an imbalance between the calories you consume and the calories you expend during the day—largely due to an increase in the consumption of foods packed with energy-dense fats and a lifestyle riddled by inactivity. Here are a few ways you can tackle inactivity without hitting a gym or breaking into a sweat: 
Eat small meals and chew slowly to keep your blood sugar levels stable and your hunger at bay. This will also help prevent you from bingeing on packaged food.
